channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Siblings can share the darndest quirks — like picking up coins & keys with their toes
item.description: Siblings — especially twins — sometimes share the strangest traits, like throwing a ball with their head or picking up keys and crayons with their toes. Researchers want to know whqt's up with that.
item.content:encoded: Siblings — especially twins — sometimes share the strangest traits, like throwing a ball with their head or picking up keys and crayons with their toes. Researchers want to know whqt's up with that.
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: How do you help patients who show up in the ER 100 times a year?
item.description: For decades, nonprofits, health insurers and hospitals have been trying to solve the problem of the people who need the emergency room again and again. Here are some of the lessons they've learned.
item.content:encoded:
For decades, nonprofits, health insurers and hospitals have been trying to solve the problem of the people who need the emergency room again and again. Here are some of the lessons they've learned.

(Image credit: Douglas Sacha)
item.dc:creator: Leslie Walker

item.title: Google antitrust lawsuit closes; Steve Inskeep celebrates 20 years at Morning Edition
item.description: Google's landmark antitrust lawsuit wraps today. Steve Inskeep celebrates 20 years as Morning Edition host. After a week of silence, Biden addresses the pro-Palestinian protests on college campuses.
item.content:encoded:
Google's landmark antitrust lawsuit wraps today. Steve Inskeep celebrates 20 years as Morning Edition host. After a week of silence, Biden addresses the pro-Palestinian protests on college campuses.

(Image credit: Spencer Platt)
item.dc:creator: Suzanne Nuyen

item.title: Apple shows its steepest quarterly decline in iPhone sales since pandemic's outset
item.description: The 10% drop in year-over-year iPhone sales for the January-March period is latest sign of weakness in a product that generates most of Apple's revenue.
item.content:encoded:
The 10% drop in year-over-year iPhone sales for the January-March period is latest sign of weakness in a product that generates most of Apple's revenue.

(Image credit: Mark Lennihan)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Hobbyist photographer snaps photo of extremely rare bird in 1st U.S. sighting
item.description: Michael Sanchez was testing out his new camera when he happened upon a feathered subject. The blue rock-thrush he photographed on the coast of northern Oregon last week has excited the birding world.
item.content:encoded: Michael Sanchez was testing out his new camera when he happened upon a feathered subject. The blue rock-thrush he photographed on the coast of northern Oregon last week has excited the birding world.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bowman

item.title: Biden is giving the Medal of Freedom to a who's who of Democrats (and Katie Ledecky)
item.description: President Biden is giving the nation's highest civilian honor to 19 people, a list that includes civil rights leaders, trailblazers and an unusually large contingent of high-profile Democrats.
item.content:encoded:
President Biden is giving the nation's highest civilian honor to 19 people, a list that includes civil rights leaders, trailblazers and an unusually large contingent of high-profile Democrats.

(Image credit: Kent Nishimura)
item.dc:creator: Deepa Shivaram

item.title: Black lawmakers reintroduce federal CROWN Act legislation to ban hair discrimination
item.description: The bill which was previously passed in the House in 2019 and 2022 but blocked in the Senate, aims to end race-based hair discrimination in schools and workplaces.
item.content:encoded:
The bill which was previously passed in the House in 2019 and 2022 but blocked in the Senate, aims to end race-based hair discrimination in schools and workplaces.

(Image credit: Joey Cappelletti)
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Franklin

item.title: After a boom in cash aid to tackle poverty, some states are now banning it
item.description: Four states so far have passed laws prohibiting the use of public money for no-strings cash aid. Advocates for basic income say the backlash is being fueled by a conservative think tank.
item.content:encoded:
Four states so far have passed laws prohibiting the use of public money for no-strings cash aid. Advocates for basic income say the backlash is being fueled by a conservative think tank.

(Image credit: olando_o)
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Ludden

item.title: Which celebrity feud escalated this week? Find out in the news quiz
item.description: Where's the beef? What's the deal with marijuana? Why does this read like a '90s stand-up script? The answer to at least some of these questions can be found in the quiz. Were you paying attention?
item.content:encoded: Where's the beef? What's the deal with marijuana? Why does this read like a '90s stand-up script? The answer to at least some of these questions can be found in the quiz. Were you paying attention?
item.dc:creator: Holly J. Morris

item.title: Launching an effective bird flu vaccine quickly could be tough, scientists warn
item.description: Federal health officials say the U.S. has the building blocks to make a vaccine to protect humans from bird flu, if needed. But experts warn we're nowhere near prepared for another pandemic.
item.content:encoded:
Federal health officials say the U.S. has the building blocks to make a vaccine to protect humans from bird flu, if needed. But experts warn we're nowhere near prepared for another pandemic.

(Image credit: skodonnell)
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein
